author: Court_esy
body:
Most are on 7nm or similar. Intel still struggles with their 10nm and releases another 14nm refresh soon (short Intel), while AMD is working on 7nm+ coming this year. 

Apple has been rumored to be using most of TSMC‘s 5nm production for this years iPhone / iPad generation. 

Nvidia‘s current Turing architecture is still more powerful than the current 7nm AMD gpus. Since they have had such a big lead on AMD I would expect them to have 7nm Ampere ready the moment big Navi drops.

author: 03z06
body:
AMD is a fabless company. They contract our their manufacturing to TSMC and probably still some global foundries. As such they don't have to spend any money on keeping their fabs up to date, however they have to pay whatever cost tsmc or global foundries charges per wafer.

Conversely, micron and Intel operate their own fabs. They have to spend billions keeping these fabs up to date, however they pay no premium when it comes to manufacturing as they own the fabs. I would think this is where the biggest difference in cap ex comes from.

author: Ardesic53
body:
Uh who gives a shit about BECKY in terms of the CPU/processor market? 

Its all about $CHAD with his new XBOX series X or his new PS5. In total, 125 million XB1 and PS5 were sold in the last 7 years. On average thats 17.9 million Xbox/PS. Thats a lot of money for AMD. When the XSX and PS5 get sold, more are about to be sold. Along with the fact that (I dont know the ticker for nerds), PC nerds buy AMD and NVDA instead of INTC because they know that AMD is better. Theres apparently 1.2 billion PC gamers, lets say 10% of them have the money and knowledge to build their own PCs and dont just buy a RZR laptop or a normal laptop that they can play some games on. Thats another 120 millions AMD/INTC buyers there. Lets say 40% of them buy AMD instead of INTC - thats 48 million people buying it. From what Ive seen, my friends buy a new CPU every 2 to 3 years so thats 16 million a year on average using conservative figures. 

So currently 17 + 16 = 33 million users on average of AMD. 


Now lets talk about AMD encroaching into the data centre market. Cloud computing becomes more and more important everyday and who wants expensive shitty stuff made by immigrants only hired to fill a bullshit diversity quota so the CEO can watch his wife get pounded by Jamal, the Nigerian with no qualifications, to fulfil his interracial cuck fetishes? Jamal used to work at a mine before for INTC before they decided to use 'conflict free resources' to look good and all that did was raise unemployment and crime in low income areas in the Congo so INTC not wanting to create a massive epidemic of poverty, decided to hire people like Jamal and his entire family. author: WhyDoYouBlock
body:
OK, so this depends on what your goal is.

For long-term investments I would invest in MSFT, AAPL, maybe NFLX and SPY. You could gamble a couple hundred on options, but you would need time to watch them so that you don't get burned badly.

For short-term, you could look into CGC (I know LOLWEED, but they're stable financially), and AMD (could drop again like the two other times so be careful)

You could also play earnings, meaning buying stock before they announce earnings and see if the stock jumps up. Here's a [calendar](https://imgur.com/a/P9Ou2MR) for this months earnings report. Lots of big names this month so there are a few plays you could make, like AMD and INTC (Intel), or go with a bank like C, JPM, GS, BAC, PNC and more

author: gbplfnt
ExceptionallyGreat
body:
Short answer is No.

&#x200B;

* Do some research into AMD gaining ground in server market segment.
   * In my humble opinion this is going to be the driving force for AMD share value in next few quarters.
* They are also generating excitement among the desktop market, which means more revenue on that front.
   * For instance they currently occupy top 11 spots on amazon best selling CPUs [https://www.amazon.com/gp/bestsellers/pc/229189/ref=pd\_zg\_hrsr\_pc](https://www.amazon.com/gp/bestsellers/pc/229189/ref=pd_zg_hrsr_pc)
* Their Laptop processor has been lagging behind Intel, but they are starting to pay attention to that segment recently.
   * Their mobile products are improving, and they might gain a little bump from this segment in a couple of quarters.
* They have continuous revenue coming in from inclusion in gaming consoles likes XBox and PS4, and they have future security in that segment.
* In the GPU market nVidia is no doubt the king due to gaming performance and API's for deep learning and AI.
   * I am not expecting much from AMD in this segment right now, but any surprise would cause a positive bump.

Note: I started investing in AMD over three years ago when it was still under $7, because I believed they have the biggest potential for growth among their competition. Now three years later, I think they are in a much better position to deliver and take their growth a lot further. That is why I am buying and accumulating shares these days, which I am planning on holding till I retire or find something with better potential for growth.

Please do your own due diligence before investing, and/or giving investing advice to family members and friends. Everyone has different goals and expectations for investment.

author: BukkakeKing69
body:
The hype behind AMD is that they are wiping the floor with Intel. If they can sustain and widen their edge they are set to grow massively. ~$220MM vs $19B revenue from Intel. It's practically a 100x increase if that were to outright flip. About a 35x increase if they steal half Intel's market. Their sales would expand from about $6B to $35 - 40B. Right now AMD's market cap is 1/5 that of Intel so if you fervently believe in AMD's story you're looking at a multibagger even from these elevated levels.

That said, if Intel gets control back AMD's stock is primed to lose like 90% of its value. So this is a very high risk high reward play. I like AMD's odds imo they have always done a lot with a little, and their partnership with TSMC is set to help them stay ahead of Intel with their foundry woes.

author: PeterMichaelPaints
body:
In all seriousness. Yes. When AMD released its chip sets a few months ago they were, and are, better performing than Intel chips and at a lower price. You will see AMD chips in most consumer products over the next 2-3 years simply because manufacturers can create better products at lower costs. Some of the new low budget gaming laptops have already rolled out with AMD, and people are going to be making PCs with AMD. I also think this puts Intel in a bind because they have been the king for years,but now there is a contender.

Stocks can go anywhere based on emotion. I think we may see 50 on AMD and then a sell off. I think the stock is worth more than that, but price and value are different things.

Don't invest more than you are willing to lose. If you don't actually want to tie up money, learn about futures and options strategies. MIT has a lot of stuff online for free.

Do not quit your job. Do not go full retard.

Honestly I feel odd making a real response to someone rather than my usual shit posts. I'm going to take a nap on my yacht. Later.

author: tatmanblue
body:
IKR!

I think there's more life in AMD.  They are winning the desktop CPU battle.   Intel CPUs are overpriced in this area.   I am seeing increasing number of desktop systems offering AMD chips.   For a while there, that was practically unseen in the retail market.

AMD also has their own graphics card, which Intel cannot compete with.   Graphic cards have value beyond gaming:  crypto functions like crypto coin, AI, and VR (which has applications way beyond just gaming).  Nvidia is winning the GPU battle but AMD is making gains in this area again.   It remains to be seen where AMD lands in this space.

I think AMD has growth ahead of themselves.  AMD is ideally positioned in the desktop CPU market with room to grow.  If they can continue with their gains the graphics card space, they will have even more headway.

When it comes to closing a position, that's a personal decision.  I usually opt to take my gains and not allow myself to get into FOMO situation.

  
(edited for comment below)

author: FloundersEdition
body:
many reason:

* bears got burned, they retreated/covered short positions for now
* fonds bought shares for their prospects ("we invested in the biggest winner 2018 and 2019, we are good")
* noone wants Intel's "best server CPUs". hughe power draw, can't be cooled, no supply **at all** (not even price was announced). it was announced 6 months ago, some investors might believed Intels claims earlier, noone believes it now. it's a hughe difference, whether you supply 28 cores per socket or 56 cores. for their complete lineup: no PCIe 4.0 and only 48 PCIe lanes at best (EPYC has up to 128 PCIe 4.0 lanes!), it's becoming clearer every day: Intel will not be competitive for highest-end servers for at least 2 years (likely even 3-4) and AMD will be the biggest winner. Rome already get much better traction and qualified much faster than Naples, Milan likely coming mid year and it will qualify fast too
* new 7nm Zen 2 with 8 cores Renoir-APU and better memory controller (huge power savings, clockspeed gains, IPC gains, better dealing with bandwith bottleneck) are expected tomorrow/very early this year (increased cadence compared to last years), while Intel has capacity and node issues. Intel tries to cut iGPU for desktop to regain capacity, but they samewhat forfeit marketshare with this call. OEMs have to use discret graphics, which they hate for Budget PCs (additional cost, additional power supply...). a refresh with better graphics can be expected ready for holiday season (van Gogh)
* overall better economy forecast and china deal, so likely higher demand, Intel cannot supply processors, so AMD will even more
* AMD ordered a **huge** amount of TSMCs wafer capacity, so they made a call
* there is still the possibility of Apple using Zen for MacBooks and Macs, it's only clear that they drop Intel this year. Apple may use it's own chips, but that's quite a barrier (x86 -> ARM) and they use AMD GPUs
* Nvidia has yield issues, probably their line up is delayed a few months

author: sankalp89
body:
Help me out in this AMD situation!!  

My position summary-
Long $20 Jan 15 2021 AMD Calls
Short $40 Jan 15 2021 AMD Calls

Back in April 2019, I figured that AMD options sell at very nice juicy premiums and AMD is also among the top ten most traded Options vehicle most of the time. I formed a bullish forecast on AMD when it appeared that it'll outsmart Intel in the nanometer race. That was when I decided to enter AMD. 

I opened five LEAP contracts for Jan 15 2021 expiration at an average of $1400 per contract. At the time AMD was trading at about $27 and it traded in a channel of $27-33 for several months. I made about $2500 (or about $500 per contract) just by selling premium on weekly calls. 

My problem started in October when AMD started picking up wildly. In just a matter of 90 days, it went up from $28 to $51. I didn't want to let go of my AMD long position, so I kept rolling out my short calls in time to avoid risk of being called away. I reached at a point that my Poor Man's Covered Call converted into a Vertical Spread for Jan 2021 expiration. My spread is long 20 - short 40 C. I can't roll any further. At this moment, the whole spread is selling for $1500. And at the time of expiration, the entire extrinsic value of the short option will collapse and it'll be selling at the width of the strikes or $2000.   


My question is - What should I do in this case if I want to hang on to AMD since my forecast for AMD is that it'll go further up from here?

Since there is very tiny extrinsic left in my long call, I'm thinking of exercising my long call @ 20 per share and use them as collateral instead. What this will get me? I will be able to roll my short call further than just Jan 2021.

author: throwawayinvestacct
body:
>I am having a tough time deciding between VTI or a low expense dividend ETF like VYM or SPYD. The dividends will be tax free and my 401k account has a big percentage of VTI, thought it might be another way to diversify.

Funds like VYM and SPYD overlap almost entirely with VTI. E.g., I don't know if this tool is perfect, but it indicates that [95.3% of VYM's holdings are also owned by VTI](https://www.etfrc.com/funds/overlap.php). Just look at the [top VYM holdings](https://www.morningstar.com/etfs/arcx/vym/portfolio): JPMorgan, J&J, P&G, Exxon, AT&T, Intel, etc. They're all also [top holdings of VTI](https://www.morningstar.com/etfs/arcx/vti/portfolio).

The point is, adding a US-large-cap fund focused on high dividend yield doesn't *diversify* you from a US total market fund, it simply *concentrates* your portfolio into that portion of the overall US market.
